name: Normal Heart Sounds
searchText: Normal heart sounds, normal
shortSummary: The physiological sounds made by the heart
summary: Normal heart sounds are the physiological sounds that the heart makes when it beats. The first heart sound (S1) corresponds to the closure of the atrioventricular valves (mitral and tricuspid) and marks the start of ventricular systole. The second heart sound (S2) corresponds to the closure of the aortic and pulmonary valves and marks the end of ventricular systole. Normal heart sounds do not rule out cardiac disease as many heart diseases can have normal heart sounds.
signs: S1 followed by S2
S2 can be split physiologically
A 3rd heart sound (S3) can occur in healthy individuals, but may also be pathological
A 4th heart sound (S4) is not normal

murmurs.name: Normal Heart Sounds 1
murmurs.description: Normal heart sounds with S1 followed by S2, heard throughout the precordium.

murmurs.name: Normal Heart Sounds 2
murmurs.description: Normal heart sounds with S1 followed by S2, heard throughout the precordium. The heart rate is irregular due to sinus arrhythmia (the variation occurs periodically and is associated with respiration, unlike atrial fibrillation). The heart rate increases slightly during inspiration due to a lower intrathoracic pressure, which decreases aortic/carotid baroceptor firing and hence decreases vagal tone. During expiration, the intrathoracic pressure rises, which increases baroceptor firing and hence increases vagal tone and decreases the heart rate. Sinus arrhythmia usually occurs in young and healthy individuals and it is less common in the elderly (due to baroceptor failure). Even though auscultation can help to identify the underlying rhythm, an ECG is needed for confirmation.

murmurs.name: Normal Heart Sounds 3
murmurs.description: Normal heart sounds with no additional murmurs. The rhythm is mostly sinus rhythm, but ectopics are also appreciated. Ectopics are usually heard as a loud S1 with either a quiet or absent S2. S1 is loud because ventricular contraction starts early, when the mitral (and tricuspid) valve leaflets are widely apart in diastole, so a loud sound is created when the leaflets hit one another. S2 is often absent as the ventricle has not had much time to fill and the contraction may not be forceful enough to open the aortic and pulmonary valves. There is often then a compensatory pause after an ectopic beat. Ectopic beats can be felt by the patient and may induce a cough, but they are mostly asymptomatic. Whilst small numbers of ventricular ectopics are physiological, frequent ectopics may indicate an underlying pathology. Even though auscultation can help to identify the underlying rhythm, an ECG is needed for confirmation.

murmurs.name: Normal Heart Sounds 4
murmurs.description: Normal heart sounds with no additional murmurs. This patient has atrial fibrillation. The heart rate is irregular and there is no pattern to the interval between beats. Even though auscultation can help to identify the underlying rhythm, an ECG is needed for confirmation.

murmurs.name: Normal Heart Sounds 5
murmurs.description: Normal heart sounds with S1 followed by S2, heard throughout the precordium. The heart rate is slow due to sinus bradycardia.

murmurs.name: Normal Heart Sounds 6
murmurs.description: Normal heart sounds with S1 followed by S2, heard throughout the precordium.

ecgFindings: Sinus rhythm or sinus arrhythmia are normal rhythms
Abnormal rhythms can also be accompanied by normal heart sounds
echoFindings: Either confirms the absence of significant valvular disease or may detect diseases not found on auscultation
medicalManagement: Remember many cardiac diseases do not affect the heart sounds (e.g. the majority of patients with a myocardial infarction have normal heart sounds)
The presence of abnormal heart sounds may indicate cardiac disease but can also occur physiologically or in other disease states (e.g. flow murmurs in pregnancy or anaemia)
clinicalPearls: Cardiac auscultation can be used to assess pulse rate and regularity (but an ECG is needed for rhythm confirmation)
Cardiac auscultation forms just part of the overall assessment and must be taken in the context of the full clinical picture

name: Aortic Stenosis
searchText: aortic stenosis, aorta, AS, as
shortSummary: Narrowing of the aortic valve orifice
summary: Aortic stenosis is the progressive narrowing of the aortic valve orifice, restricting the flow of blood through the valve. The normal valve orifice area is 3-4 cm² and there is usually no significant pressure gradient across the valve.

symptoms.name: Dyspnoea
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: Aortic stenosis is usually asymptomatic until it becomes severe. It is mostly associated with exertional dyspnoea (due to LV pressure overload) but orthopnoea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea can occur due to resultant heart failure.

symptoms.name: Chest pain
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: Aortic stenosis is usually asymptomatic until it becomes severe. It can cause cardiac chest pain on exertion due to: 1. increased LV afterload and hence increased oxygen demand, 2. concomitant coronary disease and 3. the Venturi effect - the aortic root pressure just distal to the stenosis (where the coronary arteries originate) is relatively lower, which reduces coronary filling.

symptoms.name: Presyncope
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: Aortic stenosis can cause exertional presyncope due to the inability to sufficiently increase cardiac output when there is vasodilatation, resulting in a drop in systemic blood pressure.

symptoms.name: Syncope
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: Aortic stenosis can cause exertional syncope due to the inability to sufficiently increase cardiac output when there is vasodilatation, resulting in a drop in systemic blood pressure.

signs: Narrow pulse pressure (difference between systolic and diastolic pressures)
Slow rising pulse
Heaving apex beat
Harsh ejection systolic murmur (loudest at the right upper sternal border, on expiration and sitting forward) radiating to carotids
Quiet S2
Reverse splitting of S2
S3 (if signs of heart failure)
S4

murmurs.name: Aortic Stenosis 1
murmurs.description: An ejection systolic murmur with a clear crescendo-decrescendo character that radiates to the carotids. Even though it is audible across the precordium, it is loudest at the right upper sternal border. It is of moderate severity as S2 is still clearly audible. The heart rate is irregular due to underlying atrial fibrillation. A 4th heart sound is audible when auscultating the cardiac apex, likely indicating LVH.

murmurs.name: Aortic Stenosis 2
murmurs.description: An ejection systolic murmur with a clear crescendo-decrescendo character that radiates to the carotids. It is loudest at the right upper sternal border and there is an associated palpable thrill. The quiet S2 indicates it is severe aortic stenosis.

murmurs.name: Aortic Stenosis 3
murmurs.description: An ejection systolic murmur with a clear crescendo-decrescendo character that radiates to the carotids. It is predominantly heard at the right upper sternal border. The remaining heart sounds are quiet and difficult to auscultate. The second heart sound is particularly quiet, indicating severe aortic stenosis. This patient presented with cardiogenic shock secondary to critical aortic stenosis.

murmurs.name: Aortic Stenosis 4
murmurs.description: An ejection systolic murmur with a clear crescendo-decrescendo character that radiates to the carotids. It is heard across the precordium but is loudest at the right upper sternal border, associated with a palpable thrill. The second heart sound is relatively quiet, indicating severe aortic stenosis. The systolic murmur is relatively loud at the cardiac apex, due to Gallavardin phenomenon. This is where there is separation of the two component sounds in aortic stenosis - the harsh and loud component heard at the right upper sternal border (which radiates to the carotids) and the quieter, high-frequency, musical component heard at the apex. It is thought that the apical sound is due to vibration of the bases of the aortic cusps. It can sometimes be pansystolic in nature and hence confused with the murmur of mitral regurgitation, but in contrast, does not radiate to the axilla.

murmurs.name: Aortic Stenosis 5
murmurs.description: An ejection systolic murmur with a clear crescendo-decrescendo character that radiates to the carotids. It is loudest at the right upper sternal border. The second heart sound is loud, indicating mild-moderate aortic stenosis.

murmurs.name: Aortic Stenosis 6
murmurs.description: An ejection systolic murmur with a clear crescendo-decrescendo character that radiates to the carotids. It is loudest at the right upper sternal border. The second heart sound is loud, indicating that it is unlikely to be severe aortic stenosis.

xrayFindings: Post-stenotic dilatation of the ascending aorta
echoFindings: Confirms diagnosis and assesses cause and severity

grades.name: Mild
key: MG = Mean gradient across aortic valve

grades.name: Moderate
key: MG = Mean gradient across aortic valve

grades.name: Severe
key: MG = Mean gradient across aortic valve

clinicalPearls: Listen carefully to the quality of the second heart sound; it is often a guide to aortic stenosis severity
Once severe symptomatic aortic stenosis is confirmed, don't delay in referring for intervention as it has a high untreated mortality rate

name: Aortic Sclerosis
searchText: aortic sclerosis, aorta, thickened
shortSummary: Thickening but not narrowing of the aortic valve
summary: Aortic sclerosis is the thickening and calcification of the aortic valve leaflets, without significant obstruction of the valve orifice. As such, it is not haemodynamically significant. It is asymptomatic and usually detected incidentally by auscultation or echocardiography. Up to 1 in 3 people over the age of 65 have aortic sclerosis. It slightly increases the risk of developing aortic stenosis.

causes.name: Risk factors (similar to conventional cardiovascular risk factors)

signs: Ejection systolic murmur (loudest at the right upper sternal border) without radiation to the carotids
Normal pulse pressure and pulse volume/character
Normal S2
No signs of heart failure

murmurs.name: Aortic Sclerosis 1
murmurs.description: An ejection systolic murmur with a clear crescendo-decrescendo character can be heard loudest at the right upper sternal border. It does not radiate to the carotids (unlike aortic stenosis). Additionally, S2 is normal, which further helps to differentiate it from aortic stenosis.

murmurs.name: Aortic Sclerosis 2
murmurs.description: A quiet ejection systolic murmur with a clear crescendo-decrescendo character can be heard loudest at the right upper sternal border. It does not radiate to the carotids (unlike aortic stenosis). Additionally, S2 is normal, which further helps to differentiate it from aortic stenosis.

murmurs.name: Aortic Sclerosis 3
murmurs.description: An ejection systolic murmur with a clear crescendo-decrescendo character can be heard loudest at the right upper sternal border. It does not radiate to the carotids (unlike aortic stenosis). Additionally, S2 is normal, which further helps to differentiate it from aortic stenosis.

xrayFindings: Calcification of the aortic knuckle may be present
echoFindings: Valve thickening/calcification but no gradient or reduction in orifice area
medicalManagement: Routine surveillance not usually needed but practices vary depending on local policy
complications: Small risk of conversion to aortic stenosis (< 2% per year)
clinicalPearls: Aortic sclerosis and atherosclerosis share common risk factors, so patients are at increased risk of coronary artery disease
Ensure patients have these risk factors managed

name: Aortic Regurgitation
searchText: aortic regurgitation, aortic insufficiency, leaking, aorta, AR, ar
shortSummary: Backflow through the aortic valve in diastole
summary: Aortic regurgitation is the reversal of blood flow back through the aortic valve in diastole due to failure of the valve to close adequately. This results in progressive volume overload of the left ventricle and increased forward flow in systole.

causes.name: Dilatation of the aortic root/valvular ring
causes: Congenital connective tissue disorders e.g. Marfan syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome
Aortic vasculitis e.g. giant cell arteritis, Takayasu’s arteritis, syphilis

symptoms.name: Dyspnoea
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: Aortic regurgitation is usually asymptomatic until it becomes severe. It causes dyspnoea due to increased LV preload and causes both exertional dyspnoea and orthopnoea/paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea.

signs: Wide pulse pressure (difference between systolic and diastolic pressures)
Collapsing pulse
Quincke’s sign (nailbed pulsation)
Corrigan’s sign (visible carotid pulsation)
Müller’s sign (pulsation of the uvula)
Displaced and thrusting apex beat (LV volume overload)
Early-mid diastolic murmur (loudest at the right upper and left lower sternal borders, on expiration), systolic flow murmur

murmurs.name: Aortic Regurgitation 1
murmurs.description: There is a clear early diastolic murmur, occurring just after S2. It is loudest at the right upper and left lower sternal borders (direction of blood flow). A systolic flow murmur, which radiates to the carotids, is also audible.

murmurs.name: Aortic Regurgitation 2
murmurs.description: There is a clear early diastolic murmur, occurring just after S2. It is loudest at the right upper and left lower sternal borders (direction of blood flow). The murmur also radiates to the carotids.

murmurs.name: Aortic Regurgitation 3
murmurs.description: There is a soft early diastolic murmur, occurring just after S2, associated with a systolic flow murmur. It is loudest at the right upper and left lower sternal borders (direction of blood flow). The murmur also radiates to the carotids.

murmurs.name: Aortic Regurgitation 4
murmurs.description: There is an early diastolic murmur, occurring just after S2. It is loudest at the right upper and left lower sternal borders (direction of blood flow) and is associated with a palpable thrill. A systolic flow murmur, which radiates to the carotids, is also audible. The heart rate is irregular due to underlying atrial fibrillation.

murmurs.name: Aortic Regurgitation 5
murmurs.description: There is a soft early diastolic murmur, occurring just after S2. It is loudest at the right upper and left lower sternal borders (direction of blood flow). A systolic flow murmur, which radiates to the carotids, is also audible.

xrayFindings: Mediastinal dilatation (in aortic aneurysm or dissection)
echoFindings: Confirms diagnosis and assesses cause and severity

grades.name: Mild
key: DFR = Diastolic flow reversal in descending aorta

grades.name: Moderate
key: DFR = Diastolic flow reversal in descending aorta

grades.name: Severe
key: DFR = Diastolic flow reversal in descending aorta

percutaneousManagement: Remains experimental e.g. transcatheter aortic valve implantation (TAVI)
clinicalPearls: Acute aortic regurgitation is usually poorly tolerated as the LV does not have time to compensate

name: Mitral Stenosis
searchText: mitral stenosis, mitral valve, MS, rheumatic
shortSummary: Narrowing of the mitral valve orifice
summary: Mitral stenosis is the progressive narrowing of the mitral valve orifice, restricting the flow of blood through the valve. The normal valve orifice area is 4-6 cm² and there is usually no significant pressure gradient across the valve.

causes.name: Rheumatic fever (by far the most common)
Other
causes: Atrial myxomas can mimic mitral stenosis by obstructing the mitral valve orifice

symptoms.name: Dyspnoea
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: Mitral stenosis is usually asymptomatic until it becomes severe. It can cause dyspnoea at rest, on exertion and on lying flat (orthopnoea/paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea) due to pulmonary venous congestion.

symptoms.name: Palpitations
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: Mitral stenosis can cause atrial arrhythmias (especially atrial fibrillation) due to LA dilatation.

symptoms.name: Pedal oedema
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: Any untreated, severe left-sided valve lesions and LV impairment can cause pedal oedema due to pulmonary hypertension and resultant RV failure, although isolated left-sided disease does not cause peripheral oedema. Severe mitral stenosis is strongly associated with pulmonary hypertension.

signs: Irregular pulse if AF
Mitral facies (pink-purple patches on cheeks)
Raised JVP
Tapping non-displaced apex beat
Mid-late rumbling diastolic murmur with pre-systolic accentuation if no AF (loudest at the cardiac apex, on expiration and left lateral positioning)
Loud S1 (but quiet S1 if heavily calcified valve)
Opening snap of mitral valve in late diastole (but does not occur in the Carey-Coombs murmur from mitral valvulitis)
Graham-Steell murmur (early diastolic murmur due to pulmonary regurgitation from resultant pulmonary hypertension)
signsOfSeverity: Opening snap/murmur occurs earlier in diastole/closer to S1 due to higher pressure across valve

murmurs.name: Mitral Stenosis 1
murmurs.description: There is a clear mid-late diastolic murmur, heard best at the cardiac apex. This patient does not have atrial fibrillation and as such there is pre-systolic accentuation (increased amplitude just before the following S1) due to atrial systole. In patients with AF (which is the majority), there is no pre-systolic accentuation as there is no coordinated atrial contraction.

murmurs.name: Mitral Stenosis 2
murmurs.description: There is a quiet diastolic murmur heard at the cardiac apex. This patient has atrial fibrillation, hence there is no pre-systolic accentuation (increased amplitude just before the following S1) due to loss of atrial systole. S1 is loud due to the high left atrial pressure keeping the leaflets of the mitral valve more widely apart than normal until the end of ventricular diastole. When ventricular systole starts, the leaflets slam together loudly. If the mitral valve is heavily calcified, S1 will be quiet.

murmurs.name: Mitral Stenosis 3
murmurs.description: There is a quiet low-pitched rumbling diastolic murmur heard at the cardiac apex. It is difficult to hear, but is just audible after a few beats - listen for the absence of silence in diastole. This patient has atrial fibrillation, hence there is no pre-systolic accentuation (increased amplitude just before the following S1) due to loss of atrial systole.

ecgFindings: P mitrale (LA dilatation) if sinus rhythm
xrayFindings: Calcification of the mitral valve annulus
Widened carinal angle due to LA dilatation
echoFindings: Confirms diagnosis and assesses cause and severity

grades.name: Mild
key: MG = Mean gradient across mitral valve

grades.name: Moderate
key: MG = Mean gradient across mitral valve

grades.name: Severe
key: MG = Mean gradient across mitral valve

medicalManagement: Anticoagulation if AF (with warfarin/coumarin and not DOAC)
percutaneousManagement: If rheumatic MS then percutaneous mitral commissurotomy (PMC) is first line once valve area < 1.5 cm² (and favorable characteristics e.g. Wilkins score < 8)
Degenerative/calcific MS is not amenable to PMC
surgicalManagement: Surgical mitral valve replacement or repair is considered once valve area < 1.5 cm² (but non-favourable characteristics for PMC)
complications: RV failure and functional tricuspid regurgitation
Ortner's syndrome (LA dilatation compressing the recurrent laryngeal nerve causing hoarse voice)
clinicalPearls: Rheumatic mitral stenosis is rare and difficult to appreciate on auscultation, so if there is a clinical suspicion, listen carefully at the cardiac apex, with the patient in the left lateral position

name: Mitral Regurgitation
searchText: mitral regurgitation, mitral insufficiency, leaking, mitral valve, MR
shortSummary: Backflow through the mitral valve in systole
summary: Mitral regurgitation (MR) is the reversal of blood flow back through the mitral valve into the left atrium in ventricular systole, due to failure of the mitral valve to remain adequately closed. This results in increased left atrial pressure and increased return to the left ventricle in diastole (increased preload).

causes.name: Secondary MR (dilatation of the mitral valve ring with structurally normal leaflets)
causes: Functional MR (most common, from any cause of LV or LA dilatation e.g. heart failure, dilated cardiomyopathy

symptoms.name: Dyspnoea
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: Mitral regurgitation is usually asymptomatic until it becomes severe. It can cause dyspnoea at rest, on exertion and on lying flat (orthopnoea/paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea) due to increased LV preload and pulmonary venous congestion.

signs: Irregular pulse if AF
Displaced and thrusting apex beat
Blowing pansystolic murmur (loudest at the cardiac apex, on expiration and left lateral positioning) radiating to the axilla
Soft S1
Split S2
3rd heart sound
Signs of pulmonary hypertension (malar flush, loud P2, RV heave)

murmurs.name: Mitral Regurgitation 1
murmurs.description: There is a clear pansystolic murmur, loudest at the cardiac apex, radiating to the axilla due to severe mitral regurgitation. Its amplitude is equal throughout systole (unlike an ejection systolic murmur). There is also palpable thrill at the cardiac apex.  The heart rate is irregular due to underlying atrial fibrillation, which is common in mitral regurgitation due to left atrial dilatation.

murmurs.name: Mitral Regurgitation 2
murmurs.description: There is a clear pansystolic murmur, loudest at the cardiac apex, radiating to the axilla due to severe mitral regurgitation. Its amplitude is equal throughout systole (unlike an ejection systolic murmur).

murmurs.name: Mitral Regurgitation 3
murmurs.description: There is a clear pansystolic murmur, loudest at the cardiac apex, radiating to the axilla due to severe mitral regurgitation. Its amplitude is equal throughout systole (unlike an ejection systolic murmur). There are occasional ventricular ectopics, making the heart rate irregular, best heart at the axilla.

murmurs.name: Mitral Regurgitation 4
murmurs.description: There is a soft pansystolic murmur, loudest at the cardiac apex, radiating to the axilla, due to moderate to severe mitral regurgitation. The heart rate is irregular due to underlying atrial fibrillation. The patient is breathing heavily as they presented with acute heart failure.

murmurs.name: Mitral Regurgitation 5
murmurs.description: There is a pansystolic murmur, loudest at the apex and radiating to the axilla, from moderate functional mitral regurgitation. A 3rd heart sound is audible as a low-pitched sound after S2, but it is difficult to differentiate it from an S4 due to the tachycardia (diastole is short). This patient has severe ischaemic cardiomyopathy.

murmurs.name: Mitral Regurgitation 6
murmurs.description: There is a pansystolic murmur, loudest at the apex and radiating to the axilla, from severe mitral regurgitation, associated with a palpable thrill. A 3rd heart sound is audible (mainly at the left lower sternal border) as a low-pitched sound after S2 due to severe fluid overload and heart failure.

ecgFindings: P mitrale (LA dilatation) if sinus rhythm
echoFindings: Confirms diagnosis and assesses cause and severity

grades.name: Mild
key: PVF = Direction of pulmonary vein flow in systole

grades.name: Moderate
key: PVF = Direction of pulmonary vein flow in systole

grades.name: Severe
key: PVF = Direction of pulmonary vein flow in systole

percutaneousManagement: Transcatheter edge-to-edge repair (TEER) for inoperable secondary MR
surgicalManagement: Surgical mitral valve replacement or repair
complications: RV failure and functional tricuspid regurgitation
clinicalPearls: The LV ejection fraction may be overestimated in those with mitral regurgitation, as the LV can offload into the low pressure LA
Those with a borderline ejection fraction and moderate-severe MR are therefore actually likely have significant LV systolic dysfunction

name: Mitral Valve Prolapse
searchText: Mitral valve prolapse, MVP, mvp, floppy, flail
shortSummary: Billowing of the mitral valve leaflets in systole
summary: Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) describes the billowing of one or both of the mitral valve leaflets into the left atrium during systole, with or without mitral regurgitation. It is thought to affect around 2% of the population and is therefore the most common valvular disease in developed countries. It is usually considered benign and is often asymptomatic, but can be associated with complications. It is caused by myxomatous degeneration (involving excess proliferation of the spongiosa layer) of the valve leaflets.

causes.name: Primary
causes: Myxomatous degeneration in the absence of a connective tissue disease

symptoms.name: Palpitations
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: Mitral valve prolapse can cause palpitations due to 1. an element of associated autonomic dysfunction, 2. atrial arrhythmias and ectopics and 3. more significant arrhythmias such as ventricular tachycardia (thought to be due to papillary muscle fibrosis and mechanical stretch).

symptoms.name: Chest pain
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: It is not fully understood why mitral valve prolapse can cause chest pain in some patients. The character of the pain is usually not classical cardiac pain.

symptoms.name: Presyncope
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: Mitral valve prolapse can cause presyncope due to cardiac arrhythmias – ventricular tachycardia can be caused by papillary muscle fibrosis and mechanical stretch. There may also be an element of autonomic dysfunction.

symptoms.name: Syncope
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: Mitral valve prolapse can cause syncope due to cardiac arrhythmias – ventricular tachycardia can be caused by papillary muscle fibrosis and mechanical stretch. There may also be an element of autonomic dysfunction.

symptoms.name: Sudden death
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: Mitral valve prolapse can cause sudden cardiac death due to cardiac arrhythmias – ventricular tachycardia can be caused by papillary muscle fibrosis and mechanical stretch. There may also be an element of autonomic dysfunction.

signs: Mid-systolic click (occurs when the leaflets prolapse)
Late systolic murmur after the click (if there is mitral regurgitation)
In more severe prolapse, the click and murmur occur earlier in systole
Worse on Valsalva manoeuvre (c.f. most other murmurs)

murmurs.name: Mitral Valve Prolapse 1
murmurs.description: There is a clear late systolic murmur, loudest at the cardiac apex, radiating to the axilla. There is a mid-systolic click, but it is difficult to hear as it is obscured by the murmur. The click is caused by leaflet prolapse and the late systolic murmur is caused by subsequent mitral regurgitation.

murmurs.name: Mitral Valve Prolapse 2
murmurs.description: There is a mid-late systolic murmur, loudest at the cardiac apex, radiating to the axilla. S1 is relatively quiet and the murmur occurs relatively early in systole as the mitral regurgitation is severe. A mid-systolic click is just audible but is largely obscured by the murmur.

murmurs.name: Mitral Valve Prolapse 3
murmurs.description: There is a mid-late systolic murmur, loudest at the cardiac apex, radiating to the axilla. A mid-systolic click is just audible but is largely obscured by the murmur. The heart rate is irregular due to underlying atrial fibrillation.

ecgFindings: T wave inversion in the inferior leads
echoFindings: Confirms the diagnosis and determines whether there is flail and mitral regurgitation
medicalManagement: If autonomic symptoms (e.g. palpitations/chest pain) then beta blockers are used
surgicalManagement: Mitral valve repair or replacement if severe MR
complications: Increased risk of sudden cardiac death (2x vs average population)
Mitral regurgitation (more common if flail leaflets)
clinicalPearls: Although mitral valve prolapse is associated with connective tissue diseases, most cases occur sporadically

name: Tricuspid Regurgitation
searchText: tricuspid regurgitation, tricuspid insufficiency, leaking, tricuspid valve, TR
shortSummary: Backflow through the tricuspid valve in systole
summary: Tricuspid regurgitation (TR) is the reversal of blood flow back through the tricuspid valve from the right ventricle to the right atrium in ventricular systole, due to failure of the tricuspid valve to remain adequately closed. The vast majority of cases are due to functional/secondary disease (from RV disease or pulmonary hypertension of any cause). As such, TR is usually a complication of another cardiorespiratory pathology, rather than a primary disease.

causes.name: Functional/Secondary TR (structurally normal leaflets but either RV dilatation or pulmonary hypertension)
causes: Left-sided valvular failure (e.g. mitral valve disease)

causes.name: Primary TR (structurally abnormal leaflets, rare)
causes: Carcinoid heart disease (TIPS = tricuspid insufficiency with pulmonary stenosis)

symptoms.name: Pedal oedema
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: Tricuspid regurgitation causes pedal oedema due to increased central venous pressure due to backflow of blood into the RA and central venous system.

symptoms.name: Ascites
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: Untreated severe right-sided valve lesions including tricuspid regurgitation can cause congestive hepatopathy and post-hepatic portal hypertension, resulting in transudative ascites. Pulsatile hepatomegaly may be palpated on abdominal examination.

symptoms.name: Dyspnoea
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: Isolated RV dysfunction and right-sided valve lesions are not as strongly associated with dyspnoea as left-sided heart disease. Dyspnoea may occur in tricuspid regurgitation due to the underlying pulmonary or cardiac pathology (e.g. pulmonary hypertension).

signs: Irregular pulse often (AF)
Raised JVP/giant V waves
Parasternal heave
Pansystolic murmur (loudest at left sternal border, on inspiration)
Loud P2
Ascites
Pulsatile hepatomegaly
Jaundice
Pedal oedema
Signs of left heart failure if that is the cause

murmurs.name: Tricuspid Regurgitation 1
murmurs.description: There is a pansystolic murmur, loudest at the left lower sternal border, which does not radiate, due to severe tricuspid regurgitation. The murmur from tricuspid regurgitation tends to be much quieter than mitral regurgitation (as the pressure difference between the RV and RA is less than that between the LV and LA). The cause in this patient was pulmonary hypertension from chronic hypoxic lung disease.

murmurs.name: Tricuspid Regurgitation 2
murmurs.description: There is a quiet pansystolic murmur, loudest at the left lower sternal border, which does not radiate. This patient has moderate tricuspid regurgitation. The murmur from tricuspid regurgitation tends to be much quieter than mitral regurgitation (as the pressure difference between the RV and RA is less than that between the LV and LA). The cause in this patient was idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension.

murmurs.name: Tricuspid Regurgitation 3
murmurs.description: There is a quiet pansystolic murmur, loudest at the left lower sternal border, which does not radiate. This patient has moderate-severe tricuspid regurgitation. The murmur from tricuspid regurgitation tends to be much quieter than mitral regurgitation (as the pressure difference between the RV and RA is less than that between the LV and LA). The heart rate is irregular due to underlying atrial fibrillation (due to significant right atrial dilatation from the tricuspid regurgitation).

xrayFindings: Upward displacement of diaphragm from ascites
echoFindings: Confirms diagnosis and assesses cause and severity

grades.name: Mild
key: HVF = Direction of hepatic vein flow in systole

grades.name: Moderate
key: HVF = Direction of hepatic vein flow in systole

grades.name: Severe
key: HVF = Direction of hepatic vein flow in systole

medicalManagement: Treating the underlying cause (e.g. left heart disease, lung disease or pulmonary arterial hypertension)
surgicalManagement: Surgical valve replacement or valve repair/annuloplasty for either primary disease or secondary disease without severe PH/RV failure
clinicalPearls: Tricuspid regurgitation is usually secondary, so detection should prompt a hunt for the cause

name: Pulmonary Stenosis
searchText: pulmonary stenosis, narrowed, pulmonary, PS, ps
shortSummary: A restriction to blood flow from the right ventricle
summary: Pulmonary stenosis (PS) is the restriction of blood flow leaving the right ventricle due to narrowing of the any of the following structures: the pulmonary valve orifice itself, the right ventricular infundibulum or the pulmonary artery (peripheral PS). It is usually congenital but can be acquired.

causes.name: Congenital
causes: Tetralogy of Fallot (associated with RV hypertrophy, an overriding aorta and a ventricular septal defect)
Noonan syndrome (associated with an atrial septal defect and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy)
Williams syndrome (peripheral pulmonary stenosis and supravalvular AS)

causes.name: Acquired
causes: Carcinoid heart disease (TIPS = tricuspid insufficiency with pulmonary stenosis)

symptoms.name: Failure to thrive
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: Any congenital heart disease, including pulmonary stenosis, can cause failure to thrive due to increased metabolic demand.

symptoms.name: Central cyanosis
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: Isolated pulmonary stenosis will not cause cyanosis, but it is commonly associated with other congenital anomalies, such as atrial and ventricular septal defects. RV outflow obstruction can cause preferential R-L shunting and hence deoxygenated blood entering the systemic circulation.

symptoms.name: Dyspnoea
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: Isolated RV dysfunction and right-sided valve lesions are not as strongly associated with dyspnoea as left-sided heart disease. Severe pulmonary stenosis may cause exertional dyspnoea due to obstruction of blood flow to the lungs.

symptoms.name: Pedal oedema
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: Pulmonary stenosis causes pedal oedema due to RV failure and increased central venous pressure.

signs: Harsh ejection systolic murmur (loudest at the left upper sternal border, on inspiration), radiating to the left shoulder
Murmur may be preceded by an ejection click
There may be a split S2
Parasternal heave (due to RVH)
Central cyanosis (if congenital and there is an associated right to left shunt)
Pansystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border (if tricuspid regurgitation has developed)

murmurs.name: Pulmonary Stenosis 1
murmurs.description: There is a loud and harsh ejection systolic murmur, best heard at the left upper sternal border. It has a clear crescendo-decrescendo character, but unlike aortic stenosis, it does not radiate to the carotids. It is louder and harsher than a flow murmur (which can also occur at the left upper sternal border). Additionally, it obscures S2 at the left upper sternal border.

xrayFindings: Prominent main pulmonary artery due to post-stenotic dilatation
echoFindings: Confirms diagnosis and assesses cause and severity

grades.name: Mild
key: PG = Peak gradient across pulmonary valve

grades.name: Moderate
key: PG = Peak gradient across pulmonary valve

grades.name: Severe
key: PG = Peak gradient across pulmonary valve

percutaneousManagement: Severe symptomatic disease without significant regurgitation or other cardiac lesions can be treated with balloon valvotomy
surgicalManagement: Surgical pulmonary valve replacement for severe symptomatic disease with regurgitation or other concomitant lesions (e.g. TOF repair)
clinicalPearls: Although congenial pulmonary stenosis can occur in isolation, it is often accompanied by other defects

name: Pulmonary Regurgitation
searchText: pulmonary regurgitation, pulmonary insufficiency, leaking, pulmonary, PR, pr
shortSummary: Backflow through the pulmonary valve in diastole
summary: Pulmonary regurgitation (PR) is the reversal of blood flow back through the pulmonary valve in diastole due to failure of the valve to close adequately. Trivial-mild PR is common and usually benign, however significant PR can result in progressive volume overload and failure of the right ventricle. PR is usually asymptomatic before this point.

causes.name: Congenital
causes: Post repair/valvotomy for pulmonary stenosis in Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

causes.name: Secondary to pulmonary hypertension of any cause

symptoms.name: Pedal oedema
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: Pulmonary regurgitation causes pedal oedema due to RV failure and increased central venous pressure.

symptoms.name: Dyspnoea
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: Isolated RV dysfunction and right-sided valve lesions are not as strongly associated with dyspnoea as left-sided heart disease. Significant pulmonary regurgitation may cause dyspnoea due to RV volume overload and hence eventually RV failure and reduced forward flow to the lungs.

symptoms.name: Palpitations
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: Pulmonary regurgitation is associated with RV dilatation and failure, which can result in ventricular tachycardia.

symptoms.name: Ascites
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: Untreated severe right-sided valve lesions including pulmonary regurgitation can cause congestive hepatopathy and post-hepatic portal hypertension, resulting in transudative ascites.

signs: Soft early diastolic murmur (loudest at the left upper sternal border, in inspiration)
In those with pulmonary hypertension the murmur is longer lasting than in those without
Signs of RV failure (e.g. raised JVP, pedal oedema)
Pansystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border (if tricuspid regurgitation has developed)
S3 can be present from volume overload

murmurs.name: PR 1
murmurs.description: There is a soft early diastolic murmur, occurring just after S2, due to severe pulmonary regurgitation. It is loudest at the left upper sternal border.

echoFindings: Confirms diagnosis and assesses cause and severity

key: % Jet Width = Width of regurgitant jet relative to RVOT
DFR = diastolic flow reversal in the pulmonary artery branches
% Jet Width = Width of regurgitant jet relative to RVOT
DFR = diastolic flow reversal in the pulmonary artery branches

grades.name: Significant
key: % Jet Width = Width of regurgitant jet relative to RVOT
DFR = diastolic flow reversal in the pulmonary artery branches

percutaneousManagement: Remains experimental e.g. transcatheter pulmonary valve implantation
surgicalManagement: Surgical pulmonary valve replacement required for severe symptomatic PR
complications: Ventricular arrhythmias and sudden cardiac death (especially in cases of repaired TOF)
clinicalPearls: Trivial-mild pulmonary regurgitation is common and does not usually require any specific management or follow up

name: Flow Murmur
searchText: Physiological flow murmur
shortSummary: A murmur in a structurally normal heart
summary: A flow murmur is the sound made by turbulence from an increased flow of blood through a structurally normal heart. Flow murmurs are very common and are almost always benign in that they do not represent true cardiac disease. The below signs can distinguish them from valvular disease such as aortic and pulmonary stenosis.
signs: Soft ejection or mid systolic murmur (grade  ≤2/6)
Loudest at the left sternal border
Does not radiate to the carotids or axilla
Changes with position of the patient
Often a clear physiological or pathological state present
Normal first and second heart sounds
Normal JVP and apex beat
Reduces with valsalva manoeuvre
Patient is asymptomatic

murmurs.name: Flow Murmur 1
murmurs.description: A soft ejection systolic murmur can be heard at the left upper and lower sternal border. It can be heard very quietly elsewhere, but it does not radiate to the carotids or axilla. Additionally, S1 and S2 are normal.

murmurs.name: Flow Murmur 2
murmurs.description: A soft ejection systolic murmur can be heard at the left upper and lower sternal border. It can be heard very quietly elsewhere but it does not radiate to the carotids or axilla. Additionally, S1 and S2 are normal.

echoFindings: Not usually needed but likely to be normal if performed
medicalManagement: Management of the cause or expectant management
clinicalPearls: Patients suspected to have a flow murmur should be re-examined after resolution of the cause to ensure the murmur has resolved

name: Split S1
searchText: Split first heart sound, S1, M1, T1
shortSummary: Splitting of the first heart sound into its 2 components
summary: The first heart sound represents the closure of the mitral valve (M1) and the tricuspid valve (T1). Usually, these occur almost simultaneously such that the two components cannot be distinguished on auscultation. Splitting occurs when there is a slight delay between the closure of the mitral and tricuspid valves such that M1 and then T1 can be heard separately. This can occur physiologically, but wide splitting can indicate pathology.

causes.name: Widened splitting
causes: Right bundle branch block (RBBB) - electrical impulse to RV delayed

signs: S1 can be heard as two separate sounds (M1 and then T1)
Usually M1 can be heard across the precordium but T1 is best heard at the left lower sternal border as it is quieter, so splitting is best appreciated in this location

murmurs.name: Split S1 1
murmurs.description: There is subtle splitting of the first heart sound due to underlying right bundle branch block (RBBB), which delays the electrical impulse reaching the right ventricle and hence delays the closure of the tricuspid valve. There is no corresponding splitting of the second heart sound, which can also occur in RBBB. The split is best auscultated at the left lower sternal border because in other positions, T1 cannot be auscultated well.

medicalManagement: Investigation is not required for a physiologically split S1 in the absence of symptoms
If unexplained cardiac symptoms are present or the S1 has wide or fixed splitting, further investigation is required
clinicalPearls: The relative loudness of S1 and S2 can also indicate specific pathology

references.text: Clinical Methods: The History, Physical, and Laboratory Examinations

name: Split S2
searchText: Split second heart sound, S2, A2, P2
shortSummary: Splitting of the second heart sound into its 2 components
summary: The second heart sound represents the closure of the aortic valve (A2) and the pulmonary valve (P2). Usually, these occur almost simultaneously such that the two components cannot be distinguished on auscultation. Splitting occurs when there is a slight delay between the closure of the aortic and pulmonary valves such that A2 and then P2 can be heard separately. This most commonly occurs physiologically with inspiration and disappears with expiration, but wider or fixed splitting can indicate pathology.

causes.name: Physiological (with respiratory variation)
causes: Inspiration causes a decrease in intrathoracic pressure
This causes increased RV filling and decreased LV filling
The RV takes longer to eject blood than the LV, so the closure of the pulmonary valve is delayed compared to the aortic valve
In expiration, the splitting is reduced/obliterated

causes.name: Widened splitting (with respiratory variation)
causes: Right bundle branch block (RBBB) - electrical impulse to RV delayed

causes.name: Fixed splitting (no respiratory variation)
causes: Atrial septal defect (RV always filled more than LV irrespective of respiration)

signs: S1 is followed by A2 and then P2
Listen carefully for variation in the degree of splitting with respiration
Other murmurs may indicate the cause e.g. an ejection systolic murmur in PS or ASD

murmurs.name: Split S2 1
murmurs.description: There is physiological splitting of the second heart sound into A2 and P2, occurring mostly during inspiration. The split is most clearly audible at the left upper sternal border as this is where the pulmonary valve can be most clearly auscultated.

murmurs.name: Split S2 2
murmurs.description: There is widened splitting of the second heart sound due to underlying right bundle branch block, which delays the electrical impulse reaching the right ventricle and hence delays the closure of the pulmonary valve. There is respiratory variation and hence the widened splitting is not fixed. The split is only audible at the left upper and lower sternal border because in other positions, P2 cannot be auscultated well.

murmurs.name: Split S2 3
murmurs.description: There is fixed and wide splitting of the second heart sound. This patient has an atrial septal defect (ASD) and a systolic murmur from increased flow across the pulmonary valve is also audible. The split S2 is fixed in that it does not vary with respiration because this does not change the pressure gradient between the LA and RA in an ASD.

medicalManagement: Investigation is not required for a physiologically split S2 in the absence of symptoms
If unexplained cardiac symptoms are present or the S2 has wide or fixed splitting, further investigation is required
clinicalPearls: Listen for changes in the degree of splitting with respiration to determine the cause

references.text: Clinical Methods: The History, Physical, and Laboratory Examinations

name: 3rd Heart Sound
searchText: third, 3rd, heart sound, s3, ventricular gallop
shortSummary: An additional sound at the start of diastole
summary: A 3rd heart sound (S3) is a very low-pitched sound occurring at the start of diastole, just after S2. It is thought to be due to rapid passive filling of a highly compliant left ventricle, just after the opening of the mitral valve. It is most commonly associated with volume overload and heart failure but unlike a 4th heart sound, can also occur in some physiological states.

causes.name: Systolic dysfunction/fluid overload
causes: Volume overloading valvular disease (e.g. aortic or mitral regurgitation)

signs: A very low-pitched sound occurring soon after S2
Best heard with the patient in the left lateral position, with the bell of the stethoscope, at the apex
Differentiated from a split S2 as this is high-pitched and the two sounds are very close together
May be associated signs of heart failure (e.g. raised JVP or bibasal crepitations

murmurs.name: 3rd Heart Sound 1
murmurs.description: A 3rd heart sound is audible as a low-pitched sound just after S2. It is loudest at the apex. This patient was admitted with a severe heart failure exacerbation.

murmurs.name: 3rd Heart Sound 2
murmurs.description: A 3rd heart sound is audible as a low-pitched sound after S2, but it is difficult to differentiate it from an S4 due to the tachycardia (diastole is short). It is loudest at the left lower sternal border. There is also a pansystolic murmur at the apex, radiating to the axilla, due to functional mitral regurgitation. This patient has severe LV failure.

murmurs.name: 3rd Heart Sound 3
murmurs.description: A 3rd heart sound is audible as a low-pitched sound just after S2 at the left lower sternal border and apex.

murmurs.name: 3rd Heart Sound 4
murmurs.description: A 3rd heart sound is audible as a low-pitched sound after S2, but it is difficult to differentiate it from an S4 due to the tachycardia (diastole is short). It is loudest at the left lower sternal border. There is also a pansystolic murmur at the apex, radiating to the axilla, due to functional mitral regurgitation. This patient has severe LV failure.

medicalManagement: Investigation and treatment of the underlying cause
clinicalPearls: Listen carefully for an S3 when performing a fluid balance assessment

references.text: Clinical Methods: The History, Physical, and Laboratory Examinations

name: 4th Heart Sound
searchText: fourth, 4th, heart sound, s4, atrial gallop
shortSummary: An additional sound at the end of diastole
summary: A 4th heart sound (S4) is a low-pitched sound occurring at the end of diastole, just before S1. It is almost always pathological. It is thought to be due to turbulence created by the atria contracting against excessively stiff ventricular walls in late diastole.

murmurs.name: 4th Heart Sound 1
murmurs.description: A 4th heart sound is audible as a low-pitched sound at the end of diastole, just before the next S1. It is usually heard at the left lower sternal border and the cardiac apex with the bell of the stethoscope.

murmurs.name: 4th Heart Sound 2
murmurs.description: A 4th heart sound is audible as a low-pitched sound at the end of diastole, just before the next S1. It is best heard at the left lower sternal border and the cardiac apex with the bell of the stethoscope. This patient has sinus bradycardia due to high dose beta blockade.

medicalManagement: Investigation and treatment of the underlying cause
clinicalPearls: Timing the pulse is particularly important in determining the position of additional heart sounds

references.text: Clinical Methods: The History, Physical, and Laboratory Examinations

name: Atrial Septal Defect
searchText: Atrial septal defect, ASD
shortSummary: An abnormal defect in the interatrial septum
summary: An atrial septal defect (ASD) is an abnormal defect in the interatrial septum, allowing blood shunting between the atria. It is a common type of congenital heart disease, with around 1 in 1500 newborn babies affected. ASDs can either occur as an isolated defect or associated with a syndrome. The majority are asymptomatic in childhood and present in adulthood with shortness of breath, palpitations and signs of heart failure. A patent foramen ovale (PFO) is distinct from an ASD as it only opens and allows shunting under specific conditions, such as the Valsalva manoeuvre. It affects as much as 25% of the population.

causes.name: Ostium secundum ASD
causes: Due to either an enlarged foramen ovale or inadequate growth of the septum secundum

causes.name: Ostium primum ASD
causes: Actually a type of atrioventricular septal defect
Failure of the septum primum to fuse with the atrioventricular cushions
More likely to present in childhood

causes.name: Sinus venosus ASD
causes: Abnormal connection between the SVC with the superior part of the intertrial septum

symptoms.name: Dyspnoea
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: Small ASDs are usually asymptomatic (at least in childhood). Large, chronically uncorrected ASDs with significant shunts may cause dyspnoea due to pulmonary vascular remodelling/Eisenmenger syndrome, although this is much rarer than in VSDs.

symptoms.name: Palpitations
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: Large uncorrected ASDs can present in later childhood or adulthood with a variety of symptoms, including palpitations due to arrhythmias caused by RV dilatation and failure.

symptoms.name: Pedal oedema
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: Large uncorrected ASDs can cause pedal oedema due to RV failure and increased central venous pressure.

symptoms.name: Syncope
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: Small ASDs are usually asymptomatic but large ASDs can present in later childhood or adulthood with a variety of symptoms. Syncope is relatively rare but may be caused by arrhythmias from RV dilatation and failure.

signs: Ejection systolic murmur (loudest at the left upper sternal border from increased blood flow across the pulmonary valve)
A pansystolic murmur can occur in a primum ASD
Less commonly a diastolic murmur may be present from increased flow across the tricuspid valve
Fixed and widened splitting of the second heart sound is pathognomonic and best heard at the left upper sternal border
A loud P2 or parasternal heave may indicate pulmonary hypertension
Central cyanosis, clubbing and hypoxia indicate Eisenmenger syndrome

murmurs.name: ASD 1
murmurs.description: An systolic murmur can be heard loudest at the left upper sternal border with fixed and widened splitting of the second heart sound. The murmur does not radiate. The splitting is fixed in that it does not vary with respiration because this does not change the pressure gradient between the LA and RA in an ASD.

ecgFindings: Right axis deviation or incomplete RBBB in secundum ASDs
Extreme (NW) axis deviation in primum ASD
xrayFindings: Central pulmonary artery enlarged with pulmonary plethora from increased blood flow
echoFindings: Confirms diagnosis and assesses ASD size and direction of shunt
percutaneousManagement: Percutaneous device closure is first line for secundum ASDs
Usually performed once there is RV volume overload, increased pulmonary blood flow or paradoxical embolism
Should not be performed if already established Eisenmenger syndrome
surgicalManagement: Surgical closure is second line for secundum ASDs
complications: Paroxysmal embolism and associations (cryptogenic stroke/TIA, migraine, decompression sickness)
Pulmonary hypertension and Eisenmenger syndrome (pulmonary vascular resistance exceeds systemic resistance) leading to shunt reversal (R to L)
clinicalPearls: Even though an untreated ASD is a recognised cause of Eisenmenger syndrome, it is much less likely than a VSD to progress in this manner

name: Ventricular Septal Defect
searchText: Ventricular septal defect, VSD
shortSummary: An abnormal defect in the interventricular septum
summary: A ventricular septal defect (VSD) is an abnormal defect in the interventricular septum. It is the most common type of congenital heart disease in children (and second most common in adults, after a bicuspid aortic valve). Up to 90% of congenital VSDs close spontaneously and many are asymptomatic. Large VSDs are haemodynamically significant and present with failure to thrive and dyspnoea in childhood. They can be in the perimembranous (80%) or muscular (20%) portion of the septum.

causes.name: Congenital (vast majority)
causes: Due to an interruption in the embryological development of the septum
Can be an isolated defect, associated with another congenital heart disease e.g. tetralogy of Fallot or associated with a systemic syndrome e.g. Down syndrome

causes.name: Post myocardial infarction
causes: Rare in the modern era, < 1% of patients with a transmural MI

symptoms.name: Dyspnoea
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: Small congenital VSDs are usually asymptomatic. Large congenital VSDs or acquired ventricular septal ruptures cause dyspnoea due to L-R shunt and increased return of blood to the LV in diastole (LV volume overload), hence pulmonary venous congestion. Chronically, large uncorrected VSDs cause pulmonary vascular remodelling/Eisenmenger syndrome.

symptoms.name: Failure to thrive
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: Any congenital heart disease, including ventricular septal defects, can cause failure to thrive due to increased metabolic demand.

symptoms.name: Pedal oedema
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: Large congenital VSDs can cause pulmonary vascular remodelling/Eisenmenger syndrome and hence RV failure and pedal oedema.

signs: Harsh pansystolic murmur (loudest at the left lower sternal border)
Can be heard across the precordium but does not typically radiate to the carotids/axilla
Does not change with respiration (c.f. tricuspid and mitral regurgitation)
May be associated with widened splitting of S2
Louder murmurs are associated with a smaller VSD and vice versa
Handgrip manoeuvre increases severity
A diastolic murmur may be present from increased flow across the mitral valve
Central cyanosis, clubbing and hypoxia indicate Eisenmenger syndrome

murmurs.name: VSD 1
murmurs.description: A harsh pansystolic murmur can be heard throughout the precordium, mainly at the left lower sternal border. It does not radiate and does not vary with respiration, unlike tricuspid and mitral regurgitation. Additionally, a split second heart sound can be heard at the right and left upper sternal borders.

murmurs.name: VSD 2
murmurs.description: A harsh pansystolic murmur can be heard, loudest at the left lower sternal border, associated with a forceful thrill. It does not radiate and does not vary with respiration, unlike tricuspid and mitral regurgitation.

murmurs.name: VSD 3
murmurs.description: A harsh pansystolic murmur can be heard, loudest at the left lower sternal border, associated with a forceful thrill. It does not radiate. A widely-split S2 can also be appreciated at the left upper sternal border, but unlike an ASD, this is not fixed and varies with respiration.

sounds.name: Ventricular Septal Defect 3 pulmonary area
sounds.lesionName: Ventricular septal defect with split S2

ecgFindings: Large VSDs may produce RV or biventricular hypertrophy/strain pattern
xrayFindings: May show cardiomegaly (especially LA, then LV and RV enlargement)
Heart failure signs may be present
echoFindings: Confirms diagnosis and assesses VSD size and direction of shunt

grades.name: Small
key: Diameter = Percentage diameter relative to aortic annulus diameter

grades.name: Medium
key: Diameter = Percentage diameter relative to aortic annulus diameter

grades.name: Large
key: Diameter = Percentage diameter relative to aortic annulus diameter

medicalManagement: 90% of congenital VSDs close spontaneously in the first year of life
percutaneousManagement: Rarely used, mainly for those who have indications for surgery but are high risk
surgicalManagement: Surgical closure recommended for those with high pulmonary to aortic flow ratio, LV volume overload, RV pressure overload or previous infective endocarditis
Surgical closure not recommended if Eisenmenger syndrome has already developed
complications: Pulmonary hypertension and Eisenmenger syndrome (pulmonary vascular resistance exceeds systemic resistance) leading to shunt reversal (R to L)
clinicalPearls: Reducing systemic afterload/blood pressure can reduce left to right shunting across a VSD

name: HCM
searchText: Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, HOCM, HCM
shortSummary: LV hypertrophy despite normal loading conditions
summary: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) describes the abnormal thickening of LV myocardium (≥ 15 mm in end-diastole), despite normal loading conditions (i.e. no significant valvular or hypertensive disease). Although hypertrophy can affect any part of the LV, it most commonly involves the septum asymmetrically. If it causes LV outflow tract obstruction (LVOTO), it is referred to as hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM). It is usually an inherited/genetic disorder and has a prevalence of around 1 in 500. Although it can be asymptomatic, in some it has a progressive course and is thought to be the most common cause of sudden cardiac death (SCD) in athletes. It usually presents in early adulthood.

causes.name: Autosomal dominant inheritance
causes: Usually a mutation in genes encoding sarcomeric proteins
Most common are beta myosin, myosin binding protein C and troponin I
Mostly inherited but can be a new/sporadic mutation
Exhibit incomplete penetrance (not all with gene get disease) and variable expressivity (varying severity if get disease)

symptoms.name: Dyspnoea
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: HCM with outflow obstruction causes exertional dyspnoea due to LV pressure overload.

symptoms.name: Chest pain
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: HCM with outflow obstruction causes exertional chest pain due to LV pressure overload, resulting in increased oxygen demand. Impaired LV relaxation also reduces diastolic coronary filling.

symptoms.name: Palpitations
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: HCM can cause palpitations due to both atrial arrhythmias (caused by LA dilatation due to diastolic dysfunction) and malignant ventricular arrhythmias (partly caused by myocardial disarray).

symptoms.name: Presyncope
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: HCM can cause exertional presyncope due to either outflow tract obstruction or malignant arrhythmias (partly caused by myocardial disarray).

symptoms.name: Syncope
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: HCM can cause exertional syncope due to either outflow tract obstruction or malignant arrhythmias (partly caused by myocardial disarray).

symptoms.name: Sudden death
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: HCM can cause sudden cardiac death due to either outflow tract obstruction or malignant arrhythmias (due to myocardial disarray).

signs: Harsh, medium-pitched ejection systolic murmur, loudest at the left upper sternal border (due to LVOTO)
Murmur accentuated by Valsalva manoeuvre and decreases in intensity with hand-grip
Murmur may radiate to the base of the neck but not the carotids
May be an associated pansystolic murmur at the apex, radiating to the axilla due to SAM
Jerky pulse
Double apex beat, undisplaced
S4 may be present

murmurs.name: HCM 1
murmurs.description: There is a harsh, medium-pitched ejection systolic murmur, best heard at the left upper sternal border. It has a clear crescendo-decrescendo character but unlike aortic stenosis, it does not radiate to the carotids. It is associated with a palpable thrill. There is also a pansystolic murmur at the apex, radiating to the axilla, due to systolic anterior motion (SAM) of the mitral valve and secondary mitral regurgitation. These murmurs could be confused with either aortic stenosis with Gallavardin phenomenon or combined aortic stenosis with mitral regurgitation, although there is no carotid radiation. If a Valsalva manoeuvre was performed, the murmurs would be louder.

murmurs.name: HCM 2
murmurs.description: There is a soft, medium-pitched ejection systolic murmur, best heard at the left upper sternal border. It is only audible at the start of systole and does not radiate to the carotids. There is also a higher-pitched pansystolic murmur at the apex, radiating to the axilla, due to systolic anterior motion (SAM) of the mitral valve and secondary mitral regurgitation. These murmurs could be confused with either aortic stenosis with Gallavardin phenomenon or combined aortic stenosis with mitral regurgitation, although there is no carotid radiation. If a Valsalva manoeuvre was performed, the murmurs would be louder.

ecgFindings: T wave inversion in precordial leads
echoFindings: Assesses wall thickness, LVOTO/gradient and presence of SAM
CMR usually needed to confirm diagnosis
medicalManagement: If LVOTO, then beta blockers ± disopyramide
percutaneousManagement: Implantable cardioverter defibrillator for those at high risk of SCD
Alcohol septal ablation if severe LVOTO
surgicalManagement: Surgical septal myomectomy is an alternative to alcohol septal ablation
complications: Atrial arrhythmias/AF (due to LA dilatation from contracting against a stiff ventricle)
clinicalPearls: Fainting is common in young people, but if it occurs during exercise, it raises the suspicion of an underlying cardiac cause, including HCM
Manoeuvres/conditions that decrease LV filling (e.g. dehydration, Valsalva manoeuvre) decrease LV outflow tract size and worsen outflow obstruction in HCM
This worsens symptoms and increases murmur intensity
Therefore, keep patients with HCM well hydrated
When blood passes through a narrow LVOT, it speeds up to maintain equal flow (continuity equation)
In doing this, its static pressure decreases to maintain equal mechanical energy (Venturi effect)
This 'sucks' in the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve and causes SAM

name: Pericardial Friction Rub
searchText: Pericardial friction rub, pericarditis, pfr
shortSummary: A scratching sound occurring in pericarditis
summary: A pericardial friction rub is a grating, scratching sound that occurs in pericarditis due to abnormal friction between the inflamed visceral and parietal pericardium as the heart beats. It is highly specific and relatively sensitive for acute pericarditis (it is thought to occur in up to 85% of cases).

causes.name: Acute pericarditis
causes: Any cause of acute pericarditis (e.g. viral, TB, uraemic, post-infarction etc)

symptoms.name: Chest pain
symptoms.valveSymptomDescription: Acute pericarditis is classically associated with sharp central chest pain, worse on deep inspiration and on lying flat or on the left lateral side (which causes the heart to press against the pericardium more forcefully).

signs: Grating, scratching sound heard best at the left lower sternal border when leaning forward (causes maximum apposition of the visceral and parietal pericardium).

Classically triphasic, corresponding to the friction generated as the visceral and parietal pericardium move over each other at each stage of the cardiac cycle (ventricular systole, early diastole and atrial systole)
Can be mistaken for a pleural rub (but does not stop when breath-holding)
The loudness of the sound may decrease if the patient develops a pericardial effusion (layers of pericardium separated hence less friction)

murmurs.name: Pericardial Friction Rub 1
murmurs.description: A clear pericardial friction rub, heard loudest at the left lower sternal border and apex. It is triphasic, corresponding to the friction generated as the visceral and parietal pericardium move over each other at each stage of the cardiac cycle (ventricular systole, early diastole and atrial systole). This patient presented with fevers and acute sharp chest pain, worse on inspiration and leaning forward and was subsequently diagnosed with acute pericarditis.

murmurs.name: Pericardial Friction Rub 2
murmurs.description: A clear pericardial friction rub, heard loudest at the left lower sternal border and apex. It is difficult to differentiate each of the three components. Instead, it is heard as a continuous scratching sound.

murmurs.name: Pericardial Friction Rub 3
murmurs.description: A clear pericardial friction rub, heard loudest at the left lower sternal border and apex. It is mainly heard as a scratching sound in systole, but the diastolic components are just audible.

clinicalPearls: A careful history, combined with the clinical examination, is usually sufficient to diagnose pericarditis

name: Muffled Heart Sounds
searchText: Muffled heart sounds, quiet
shortSummary: Dampening of the normal heart sounds
summary: The normal S1 and S2 sounds are heard as sharp and discrete sounds. In contrast, muffled heart sounds are quieter and sound distant, as if being heard from underwater. Various pathological states can cause muffled heart sounds.

causes.name: Obesity
causes: Increased adipose tissue insulating the heart sounds

causes.name: Fluid
causes: Pericardial effusion (Beck's triad of tamponade is: muffled heart sounds, a low blood pressure and a raised JVP)

causes.name: Low cardiac output states
causes: Reduced contractile function resulting in less forceful closure of the valves

signs: Quiet sounds across the precordium (even at the apex where heart sounds should be loudest)
Heart sounds seem as if they are being heard from a distance or as if they are under water
Look for causes such as obesity or a raised JVP

murmurs.name: Muffled Heart Sounds 1
murmurs.description: Muffled heart sounds in a patient with a large pericardial effusion.

murmurs.name: Muffled Heart Sounds 2
murmurs.description: Muffled heart sounds due to obesity and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease with air trapping in the lung.

ecgFindings: A pericardial effusion may cause low voltage complexes and electrical alternans
xrayFindings: A pericardial effusion may cause a large globular heart
echoFindings: Not usually needed if muffled heart sounds are found incidentally but an urgent echo is required if a pericardial effusion is suspected
clinicalPearls: A small pericardial effusion that has developed rapidly is more likely to be haemodynamically compromising than a larger effusion that has developed over time

name: Mechanical AVR
searchText: mechanical aortic valve replacement, metallic, aorta
shortSummary: A mechanical aortic valve replacement
summary: A mechanical aortic valve replacement is performed surgically for severe aortic stenosis, severe or acute aortic regurgitation or in combination with an aortic root replacement.
signs: Particularly loud and metallic-sounding second heart sound
A midline sternotomy scar will be present
Can often hear a click from the bedside but this is not usually audible with a stethoscope
Systolic flow murmur common due to partial outflow obstruction from the valve
A quiet diastolic murmur may be normal (some degree of leakage in diastole)
A loud early diastolic murmur strongly raises the suspicion of valve failure

murmurs.name: Mechanical AVR 1
murmurs.description: The second heart sound is a loud and metallic thud, in time with the closure of the replaced aortic valve. It can be heard across the precordium, especially at the right upper sternal border. There is also a soft systolic flow murmur.

murmurs.name: Mechanical AVR 2
murmurs.description: The second heart sound is a loud and metallic thud, in time with the closure of the replaced aortic valve. It can be heard across the precordium, especially at the right upper sternal border.

murmurs.name: Mechanical AVR 3
murmurs.description: The second heart sound is a loud and metallic thud, in time with the closure of the replaced aortic valve. It can be heard across the precordium, especially at the right upper sternal border. There is also a soft systolic flow murmur.

murmurs.name: Mechanical AVR 4
murmurs.description: The second heart sound is a loud and metallic thud, in time with the closure of the replaced aortic valve. It can be heard across the precordium, especially at the right upper sternal border.

medicalManagement: Lifelong therapeutic anticoagulation (usually warfarin) to prevent valve thrombosis
Follow up determined by local protocols
complications: Valve failure (but more durable than tissue valve replacement)
clinicalPearls: When a midline sternotomy is noted on examination, the presence of lower limb vein harvesting scars can help to determine if they have undergone a CABG
The absence of these scars often indicates another procedure has been performed, the most common of which is a valve replacement

name: Mechanical MVR
searchText: mechanical mitral valve replacement, metallic, mitral
shortSummary: A mechanical mitral valve replacement
summary: A mechanical mitral valve replacement is performed surgically for severe/acute mitral regurgitation or mitral stenosis.
signs: Particularly loud and metallic-sounding first heart sound
A midline sternotomy scar will be present
Can often hear a click from the bedside but this is not usually audible with a stethoscope
A quiet diastolic flow murmur is normal
A loud systolic murmur at the cardiac apex usually indicates valve failure/regurgitation

murmurs.name: Mechanical MVR 1
murmurs.description: The first heart sound is a loud and metallic thud, in time with the closure of the replaced mitral valve. It is most notable at the cardiac apex. There is a soft systolic murmur at the right upper sternal border as this patient also has concomitant mild aortic stenosis. The heart rate is irregular due to underlying atrial fibrillation, which is common in both mitral stenosis and regurgitation and usually develops pre-valve replacement.

murmurs.name: Mechanical MVR 2
murmurs.description: The first heart sound is a loud and metallic thud, in time with the closure of the replaced mitral valve. It is most notable at the cardiac apex. There is an additional pansystolic murmur at the apex, indicating prosthetic mitral regurgitation and hence valve failure. The heart rate is irregular due to underlying atrial fibrillation, which is common in both mitral stenosis and regurgitation and usually develops pre-valve replacement.

murmurs.name: Mechanical MVR 3
murmurs.description: The first heart sound is a loud and metallic thud, in time with the closure of the replaced mitral valve. It is most notable at the cardiac apex. The heart rate is irregular due to underlying atrial fibrillation, which is common in both mitral stenosis and regurgitation and usually develops pre-valve replacement.

medicalManagement: Lifelong therapeutic anticoagulation (usually warfarin) to prevent valve thrombosis
Follow up determined by local protocols
complications: Valve failure (but more durable than tissue valve replacement)
clinicalPearls: All mechanical valve replacements need lifelong anticoagulation, so those with significant contraindications may be better served by a bioprosthetic valve replacement

name: Ventricular Assist Device
searchText: Left Right ventricular assist device, LVAD, RVAD
shortSummary: A mechanical pump for advanced heart failure
summary: A ventricular assist device (VAD) is a mechanical pump, surgically inserted in patients with advanced heart failure. VADs can assist the left ventricle (LVAD, which is the most common type), right ventricle (RVAD) or both (BiVAD). VADs can be used as a bridge to heart transplant, a bridge to recovery or as a destination therapy. Most contemporary LVADs are continuous flow pumps that extract blood from the LV apex and pump it into the aorta.
signs: The patient will have a surgical scar (usually midline sternotomy)
A driveline usually exits the patient under the xiphisternum (to provide power to the pump from an external battery pack)
Auscultation reveals a continuous loud mechanical whirring

murmurs.name: VAD 1
murmurs.description: This patient has a left ventricular assist device (LVAD) for advanced heart failure. There is a loud and continuous mechanical whirring sound, which is also palpable, but the underlying S1 and S2 can just be heard. The heart rate is irregular due to atrial fibrillation. The pitch of the whirring occasionally changes due to changes in pump speed.

murmurs.name: VAD 2
murmurs.description: This patient has a left ventricular assist device (LVAD) for advanced heart failure. There is a loud and continuous mechanical whirring sound, which is also palpable, but the underlying S1 and S2 can just be heard.

medicalManagement: Only inserted and followed up under specialist services
Lifelong therapeutic anticoagulation (usually warfarin) to prevent VAD thrombosis
Follow up determined by local protocols
complications: Haemorrhage (especially GI haemorrhage) due to anticoagulation and an increased risk of bowel angiodysplasia from continuous, non-pulsatile flow
Suction events (VAD sucks walls of the ventricle in, resulting in reduced flows or arrhythmias)
clinicalPearls: VADs extend life in those with advanced heart failure but they are inferior to a heart transplant
